intro.heading: Introduction
intro.summary: Exploration missions pose environmental challenges to astronauts, including gravitational changes and radiation, impacting the CNS. The CNS is vulnerable due to its lipid concentration and energy demands, leading to behavioral deficits. Studying these effects in humans is limited, necessitating animal models like fruit flies to understand the molecular mechanisms. This study uses Drosophila to investigate the impact of microgravity (μg) and simulated Earth gravity (1g) on the fly CNS during spaceflight.

sections.heading: MVP-Fly-01 Mission Overview
sections.summary: The MVP-Fly-01 mission on the ISS studied the effects of spaceflight, combining μg with radiation and elevated CO2. Two centrifuges maintained flies in μg (SFμg) and simulated Earth gravity (SF1g), acting as an on-orbit control. Postflight ground control mimicked spaceflight conditions. Flies were used for behavioral, morphological, and acclimation analyses.

sections.heading: Increased Activity in SFμg Flies
sections.summary: An algorithm quantified fly activity from video recordings, showing that SFμg flies exhibited significantly greater activity levels than SF1g flies. This difference was observed except around mission days 20 and 28, where initial fly emergence and high fly density might have influenced activity.

sections.heading: Behavioral and Neuronal Deficits in Microgravity
sections.summary: Postflight, climbing ability assays revealed significant deficits in SFμg males compared to Earth males. Brain staining showed a slight reduction in brain area of SFμg female flies. Morphological quantification showed a decrease in neuronal cortex area, alongside increased apoptosis and oxidative DNA damage in the brains of SFμg flies.

sections.heading: Global Omics Analysis of Brain Changes
sections.summary: Transcriptomics and proteomics analyses revealed differential expression of genes and proteins in SFμg and SF1g flies compared to Earth controls. SFμg flies showed differential expression of 1014 genes (females) and 507 genes (males) while SF1g flies showed differential expression of 80 genes (females) and 601 genes (males) compared to earth controls. The intersection within differentially expressed proteins across experimental conditions yielded more hits compared to differentially expressed genes, suggesting alterations in transcripts and protein levels when flies are reared in space conditions compared to Earth condition.

sections.heading: Metabolic Pathway and Oxidative Phosphorylation Alterations
sections.summary: Omics analysis highlighted enriched GO biological processes, including cuticle development, oxidative phosphorylation, and metabolic processes. Proteomic data of SFμg flies showed enrichment of pathways such as endocytosis, cellular metabolic responsive pathways, pyruvate metabolism, oxidative phosphorylation, and amino acid metabolism, indicating metabolic and cellular stress. Analysis of cellular respiration revealed perturbations in the biological processes and cellular components encompassing every step of the pathway.

sections.heading: Expression of Stress-Inducible Proteins
sections.summary: Spaceflight altered metabolic pathways and increased cellular stress, with significant upregulation of heat shock proteins (HSPs) in both spaceflight conditions. Increased neuronal loss, apoptosis, and oxidative damage in the fly brain confirm the effects of oxidative stress during spaceflight. Altered expression of proteins enriched in neuronal projection, neuron death, axonogenesis, and synaptic transmission was observed in SFμg flies.

sections.heading: Persistent Effects of Spaceflight Exposure
sections.summary: Proteomics analysis suggests enrichment of behavioral and aging markers in SF1g and SFμg flies, with upregulation of HSPs and downregulation of proteins associated with oxidative stress response. Longitudinally, brain morphology of SF1g and SFμg was altered compared to Earth controls. Significant reduction of DA neurons was observed early in SFμg flies.

sections.heading: Discussion
sections.summary: The study provides insights into spaceflight effects on the brain at molecular, morphological, and behavioral levels using the MVP fruit fly space habitat.

conclusion: This study provides insights into the neurological impacts of spaceflight, demonstrating that artificial gravity can partially mitigate these effects. The multi-omics approach reveals molecular changes related to stress, metabolism, and neuronal function, enhancing understanding of the risks associated with space travel.

_meta.paper_title: Artificial Gravity Partially Protects Space-induced Neurological Deficits in Drosophila melanogaster
